chief technology officer of the display
division at Intel. So I've got a lot and
a lot of knowledge about uh the Intel
OOLPC relationship. But in general um
and and I it was very difficult and um
unfortunate that that um it couldn't
have lasted longer. Um but in general
the um laptop market has really been
this laptop market the lowcost laptop
market was was I think clearly started
by one laptop per child and the work I
did in it and and many many others in in
architecting what they all thought was I
mean Craig Barrett said it was crazy
right it would never work and it was a
gadget and but but you know we did it
and Asus actually um came in who's a a
computer maker that most people have
never heard of and has shipped, you
know, 6 million laptops like like this
this little XO laptop in in the last 6
months. And so that's really gotten
industry to wake up. And you know, Dell
just showed their their competitor to
this laptop this week at a conference
called D uh the Wall Street Journal
conference. And you know HP is certainly
shown theirs and and you know Intel of
course and and there are next week at
there's a conference called Computex in
Taiwan. It's every June in Taiwan and
there will be a coming out party for
about 50 5 lowcost small laptops. So
everybody's getting in on it. The
analyst thinks it's going to be half of
the the laptop market very quickly by
2010. And I think it's terrific. I think
that, you know, that's that's the way to
to make it happen is is figure out we
should all be making laptops cheaper and
lower power and, you know, easier to
carry around. And there are some
trade-offs. The screen's a little
smaller. So, that's that's something
that my new company is really chewing on
is is how do we make a great screen
experience in in a in a in in something
that's more portable somehow, some way?
And so one thing that we we announced um
two weeks ago with OOLPC was, you know,
basically two screens, one on each side
of the laptop. So you can have a book
sort of like that or you can have a
laptop where you type here on one screen
and you got the screen up here. But it's
it's more screen real estate in a
smaller area.
Um I'm pretty excited about some of the
stuff we're doing with some of the
companies to uh basically get um
integrated touch sunlight readability
and really an ebook like look uh on the
laptop. As far as the motherboard, I
think that the days of of the CPU the
for this area, I think the CPU makers,
the the microprocessor makers are scared
because at the low
end, I mean, the word that makes that
that makes an executive at a at a a CPU
maker sort of shudder in fear is the
word commodity, right? And when you're
making lots of something for very low
cost, it's it's pretty hard not to use
that word. And so they're thinking,
well, how do we, you know, not be
commodity? And so they're trying to work
on on lower power. But what I contend
and what the design of the OOLPC laptop
shows, no matter how low power your CPU
is, it's much lower power by turning the
thing off, which is what the OOLPCXO
does. We turn off the whole motherboard
in a tenth of a second while somebody's
just pausing, looking at the screen,
thinking, you know, whatever, showing a
picture to somebody. And then if there's
a a key press event or a packet comes
over the internet, it wakes up. And so
that it it's it's sort
of opposite because the CPU makers have
so dominated the you know this sort of
march of computing so and been so
incredibly effective. But then when you
look at something at the low end, you
know, you just want to use whatever is a
pretty lowcost CPU and turn it off most
of the time because, you know, well, why
use it use it if somebody's just typing
an email and thinking or surfing the web
and or or writing a paper and thinking
about what they're going to say? They
don't need it. What they really care
about is their battery lasting for 20
hours, especially for the developing
world, but in the developed world as as
well. And so for for the CPU makers, it
it's difficult. And so I I feel their
pain and I want to help, but you know,
like I think that the future of portable
computing is all about the screen. It's
the most expensive and most power-
hungry component. And so we're trying to
improve the screen and the reading
experience because people want to be
able to read on the screen.
